newsitem.title: BOSNIA: NATO studies "reserve" force for Bosnia mission.
newsitem.headline: NATO studies "reserve" force for Bosnia mission.

text.p: Senior NATO officers are visiting Bosnia this week to prepare plans for a possible reserve force that could be deployed to back up peacekeeping troops in the country, an alliance spokesman said on Monday.

Officers from the United States, the Netherlands, Italy, Turkey and two countries outside NATO -- Poland and Romania -- are travelling to bases across the country used by the alliance-led Stabilisation Force (SFOR), spokesmen told a news conference.
"This reconnaissance is designed to enable them to gain a clear picture of the requirements should NATO decide to deploy the SFOR strategic reserve," Major Chris Riley said.

"The strategic reserve concept is designed to provide a strong reserve force outside Bosnia which can be called upon to rapidly reinforce SFOR in the event of any major crisis which may require a greater number of troops than are currently available on the ground," he said.
The 31,000-strong peace force, charged with enforcing a 1995 peace treaty in Bosnia, is due to withdraw when its mandate expires in June 1998.
But speculation persists that the alliance will be forced to extend the NATO mission to prevent another war from erupting in Bosnia, which is divided into Serb and Moslem-Croat territories.
SFOR officers declined to offer many details about the proposed "strategic reserve" but described the seven-day visit as part of NATO's long-term planning.
Colonel Steven Rausch, another spokesman for SFOR, indicated that units which could comprise the strategic reserve force would conduct military exercises later this year.
"There will be some (military) exercises later in the year and onto into next year. We are talking about a long term process," Rausch said.
"We've always had forces outside the country that could be called in if the place really went down fast...This is an effort to take a look at the long-term."
